content.title: Intravascular Ultrasound (IVUS)
content.definition: Catheter-based imaging using ultrasound to visualize the vessel lumen and wall from inside the artery or vein. Provides cross-sectional images for accurate sizing, lesion characterization, and assessment of stent apposition. Increasingly important in vascular intervention.

key_concepts.description: Miniaturized ultrasound transducer on catheter tip (20-40 MHz frequency); provides 360-degree cross-sectional images; mechanical rotation or phased array designs
Distinguishes lumen, plaque (echogenic vs echolucent), media, adventitia; identifies calcium (acoustic shadowing); detects dissection flaps, thrombus
Angiography shows lumen silhouette; IVUS shows wall structure; better for: eccentric plaque, true lumen sizing, stent apposition, dissection extent, chronic total occlusion (CTO)
Accurate vessel diameter measurement for stent selection; more accurate than angiography especially in eccentric disease; measure external elastic lamina (EEL) for true vessel size
Confirms full stent expansion and apposition; identifies edge dissection, geographic miss, malapposition; predicts stent thrombosis and restenosis if suboptimal
Essential for iliac vein stenting (May-Thurner); identifies stenosis not visible on venography; ensures adequate stent sizing and expansion
Helps identify true lumen during chronic total occlusion crossing; distinguishes true lumen from subintimal space; re-entry device guidance
EVAR sizing particularly at landing zones; identifies endoleak, dissection extent; may be used intraoperatively
Requires arterial access and catheter manipulation; additional procedure time and cost; learning curve for interpretation; cannot cross severely stenotic lesions initially
Advanced IVUS processing to characterize plaque composition (fibrous, fibro-fatty, necrotic core, dense calcium); research applications

learning_objectives: Understand IVUS technology and image interpretation
Know advantages over angiography for sizing and wall visualization
Recognize applications in stent assessment and venous intervention
Apply IVUS for optimal endovascular outcomes
clinical_pearls: Angiography shows lumen; IVUS shows wall structure
Essential for iliac vein stenting (May-Thurner) - can't size without it
Check stent apposition and expansion - predicts outcomes
Measure to EEL for true vessel size, not just lumen
Helps CTO navigation - identify true lumen
Calcium causes acoustic shadowing - identifies heavily calcified lesions
common_mistakes: Relying only on angiography for sizing (especially eccentric disease)
Not using IVUS for iliac vein stenting (undersizing common)
